internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 01-01 Define tax, taxpayer, incidence, and jurisdiction.

worksheet.stem:
Mr. Josh Kenney, a U.S. citizen and resident of Vermont, owns 100 percent of the stock of JK Services, which is incorporated under Vermont law and conducts business in four counties in the state. JK Services owns 100 percent of the stock of JK Realty, which is incorporated under Massachusetts law and conducts business in Boston.

 

b1. Identify the governments with jurisdiction to tax to Mr. JK. (You may select more than one answer. Single click the box with the question mark to produce a check mark for a correct answer and double click the box with the question mark to empty the box for a wrong answer. Any boxes left with a question mark will be automatically graded as incorrect.)

 

__ans1__

 

b2. Identify the governments with jurisdiction to tax to JK Services. (You may select more than one answer. Single click the box with the question mark to produce a check mark for a correct answer and double click the box with the question mark to empty the box for a wrong answer. Any boxes left with a question mark will be automatically graded as incorrect.)

 

__ans2__

 

b3. Identify the governments with jurisdiction to tax to JK Realty. (You may select more than one answer. Single click the box with the question mark to produce a check mark for a correct answer and double click the box with the question mark to empty the box for a wrong answer. Any boxes left with a question mark will be automatically graded as incorrect.)

 

__ans3__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
1. b-1. The government of the locality in which Mr. Kenney resides, the state government of Vermont, and the U.S. government have jurisdiction to tax Mr. Kenney.
  2. b-2. The local governments of the four counties in which JK Services conducts business, the state government of Vermont, and the U.S. government have jurisdiction to tax JK Services.
  3. b-3. The city of Boston, the state government of Massachusetts, and the U.S. government have jurisdiction to tax JK Realty.

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 01-01 Define tax, taxpayer, incidence, and jurisdiction.
Learning Objective: 01-05 Describe the taxes levied by the federal government.

worksheet.stem:
In each of the following cases, determine if the United States has jurisdiction to tax Mrs. May.

 

a. Mrs. May is a citizen of Brazil but is a permanent resident of Orlando, Florida.

 

__new__

 

b. Mrs. May is a citizen and resident of Brazil. She owns Manhattan real estate that generates $100,000 net rental income annually.

 

__new1__

 

c. Mrs. May is a citizen and resident of Brazil. She owns no property and conducts no business in the United States.

 

__new2__

 

d. Mrs. May is a U.S. citizen but is a permanent resident of São Paulo, Brazil.

 

__new3__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
1. The United States has jurisdiction to tax Mrs. May because she is a permanent resident.
  2. The United States has jurisdiction to tax Mrs. May only on the U.S. source rental income generated by the Manhattan real estate.
  3. The United States does not have jurisdiction to tax Mrs. May.
  4. The United States has jurisdiction to tax Mrs. May because she is a U.S. citizen.

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 01-01 Define tax, taxpayer, incidence, and jurisdiction.
Learning Objective: 01-05 Describe the taxes levied by the federal government.

worksheet.stem:
In each of the following cases, determine if the United States has jurisdiction to tax Mr. Tompkin.

 

a. Mr. Tompkin is a U.S. citizen but has been a permanent resident of Belgium since 1993.

 

__new__

 

b. Mr. Tompkin is a citizen and resident of Canada. He owns an apartment building in Buffalo, New York, that generates $18,000 annual net rental income.

 

__new1__

 

c. Mr. Tompkin is a citizen of Singapore but is a permanent resident of St. Louis, Missouri.

 

__new2__

 

d. Mr. Tompkin a citizen and resident of Greece, is a partner in Sophic Partnership, which conducts business in 12 countries, including the United States.

 

__new3__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
1. The United States has jurisdiction to tax Mr. Tompkin because he is a U.S citizen.
  2. The United States has jurisdiction to tax Mr. Tompkin only on the U.S. source rental income generated by the Buffalo real estate.
  3. The United States has jurisdiction to tax Mr. Tompkin because he is a permanent resident.
  4. The United States has jurisdiction to tax Mr. Tompkin on his share of the U.S. source business income generated by Sophic Partnership.

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 01-02 Express the relationship between tax base, rate, and revenue as a formula.
Topic: The Relationship between Base, Rate, and Revenue

worksheet.stem:
This year, State A raised revenues by increasing its general sales tax rate from {{[a(1)]:#,###}} percent to {{[a(2)]:#,###}} percent. Because of the increase, the volume of taxable sales declined from ${{[a(3)]:#,###}} million to ${{[a(4)]:#,###}} million. In contrast, State Z raised revenues from its {{[a(1)]:#,###}} percent sales tax by expanding the tax base to include certain retail services. The volume of services subject to tax was ${{[a(5)]:#,###}} million.

  1. Compute the additional revenue raised by State A.
  2. Compute the additional revenue raised by State Z.

 

__new__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
a.

State A:

       
Volume of sales before rate increase $ {{[a(6)]:#,###}}  
Original tax rate   {{[a(7)]:#,##0.00}}  
Revenue before rate increase $ {{[a(8)]:#,###}}  
       
Volume of sales after rate increase $ {{[a(9)]:#,###}}  
New tax rate   {{[a(10)]:#,##0.00}}  
Revenue after rate increase $ {{[a(11)]:#,###}}  
       
Additional revenue (${{[a(11)]:#,###}} − ${{[a(8)]:#,###}}) $ {{[a(12)]:#,###}}  

 

b.

State Z:

       
Volume of sales added to tax base $ {{[a(13)]:#,###}}  
Tax rate   {{[a(7)]:#,##0.00}}  
Additional revenue $ {{[a(14)]:#,###}}

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 01-02 Express the relationship between tax base, rate, and revenue as a formula.
Topic: The Relationship between Base, Rate, and Revenue

worksheet.stem:
This year, State A raised revenues by increasing its general sales tax rate from 5 percent to 6 percent. Because of the increase, the volume of taxable sales declined from $800 million to $710 million. In contrast, State Z raised revenues from its 5 percent sales tax by expanding the tax base to include certain retail services. The volume of services subject to tax was $50 million.

  1. Compute the additional revenue raised by State A.
  2. Compute the additional revenue raised by State Z.

 

__new__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
a.

State A:

       
Volume of sales before rate increase $ 800,000,000  
Original tax rate   0.05  
Revenue before rate increase $ 40,000,000  
       
Volume of sales after rate increase $ 710,000,000  
New tax rate   0.06  
Revenue after rate increase $ 42,600,000  
       
Additional revenue ($42,600,000 − $40,000,000) $ 2,600,000  

 

b.

State Z:

       
Volume of sales added to tax base $ 50,000,000  
Tax rate   0.05  
Additional revenue $ 2,500,000

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 01-02 Express the relationship between tax base, rate, and revenue as a formula.
Learning Objective: 01-03 Describe the taxes levied by local governments.

worksheet.stem:
The city of Springvale levies a tax on the value of real property located within its city limits. The tax equals [a(1)] percent of the property’s assessed value up to ${{[a(2)]:#,###}} plus {{[a(3)]:#,###}} percent of the value in excess of ${{[a(2)]:#,###}}. 

  1. Compute the tax on real property valued at ${{[a(4)]:#,###}}.
  2. Compute the tax on real property valued at ${{[a(5)]:#,###}}.

 

__ans__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
1. The property tax is ${{[a(6)]:#,###}} (${{[a(4)]:#,###}} × {{[a(1)]:#,###}}%).
  2. The property tax is ${{[a(7)]:#,###}} ([${{[a(2)]:#,###}} × {{[a(1)]:#,###}}%] + [${{[a(8)]:#,###}} × {{[a(3)]:#,###}}%]).

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 01-02 Express the relationship between tax base, rate, and revenue as a formula.
Learning Objective: 01-03 Describe the taxes levied by local governments.

worksheet.stem:
The city of Springvale levies a tax on the value of real property located within its city limits. The tax equals 2 percent of the property’s assessed value up to $500,000 plus 4 percent of the value in excess of $500,000.

  1. Compute the tax on real property valued at $415,000.
  2. Compute the tax on real property valued at $725,000.

 

__ans__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
1. The property tax is $8,300 ($415,000 × 2%).
  2. The property tax is $19,000 ([$500,000 × 2%] + [$225,000 × 4%]).

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 01-02 Express the relationship between tax base, rate, and revenue as a formula.
Learning Objective: 01-03 Describe the taxes levied by local governments.

worksheet.stem:
Monroe county levies a tax on the value of real property located within the county. The tax equals {{[a(1)]:#,###}} percent of the property's assessed value up to ${{[a(2)]:#,###}} million plus 1 percent of the value in excess of ${{[a(2)]:#,###}} million.

  1. Compute the tax on real property valued at ${{[a(4)]:#,###.00}} million.
  2. Compute the tax on real property valued at ${{[a(5)]:#,###.00}} million.

 

__ans__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
1. The property tax is ${{[a(6)]:#,###}} (${{[a(4)]:#,###.00}} million × 3%).
  2. The property tax is ${{[a(7)]:#,###}} ([$2 million × 3%] + [${{[a(8)]:#,###.0}} million × 1%]).

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 01-02 Express the relationship between tax base, rate, and revenue as a formula.
Learning Objective: 01-03 Describe the taxes levied by local governments.

worksheet.stem:
Monroe county levies a tax on the value of real property located within the county. The tax equals 3 percent of the property's assessed value up to $2 million plus 1 percent of the value in excess of $2 million.
 

  1. Compute the tax on real property valued at $1.3 million.
  2. Compute the tax on real property valued at $4.5 million.

 

__ans__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
1. The property tax is $39,000 ($1.3 million × 3%).
  2. The property tax is $85,000 ([$2 million × 3%] + [$2.5 million × 1%]).

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 01-03 Describe the taxes levied by local governments.

worksheet.stem:
This year, Lexon Company built a light industrial facility in County G. The assessed property tax value of the facility is ${{[a(1)]:#,###.0}} million. To convince Lexon to locate within its jurisdiction, the county abated its {{[a(2)]:#,###}} percent property tax for the year. Because of the local economic boom created by the new facility, the aggregate assessed value of County G’s property tax base (including the Lexon facility) increased to ${{[a(3)]:#,###.0}} million. Compute the net effect on County G’s current year tax revenue from the abatement. (Enter your answer in dollars not in millions of dollars.)

 

__new__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
Increase in County G’s aggregate assessed property tax value $ {{[a(4)]:#,###}}    
Assessed value of Lexon’s new facility   ({{[a(5)]:#,###}} )  
Net increase in County G’s tax base $ {{[a(6)]:#,###}}    
Tax rate   {{[a(7)]:#,##0.00}}    
Net effect on County G’s current year revenue $ {{[a(8)]:#,###}}

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 01-03 Describe the taxes levied by local governments.

worksheet.stem:
This year, Lexon Company built a light industrial facility in County G. The assessed property tax value of the facility is $20 million. To convince Lexon to locate within its jurisdiction, the county abated its 4 percent property tax for the year. Because of the local economic boom created by the new facility, the aggregate assessed value of County G’s property tax base (including the Lexon facility) increased to $23 million. Compute the net effect on County G’s current year tax revenue from the abatement. (Enter your answer in dollars not in millions of dollars.)

 

__new__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
Increase in County G’s aggregate assessed property tax value $ 23,000,000    
Assessed value of Lexon’s new facility   (20,000,000 )  
Net increase in County G’s tax base $ 3,000,000    
Tax rate   0.04    
Net effect on County G’s current year revenue $ 120,000

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 01-04 Describe the taxes levied by state governments.
Topic: Retail Sales, Use, and Excise Taxes

worksheet.stem:
Heliot Company operates its business in State H, which levies a {{[a(1)]:#,###}} percent sales and use tax. This year, Heliot purchased a ${{[a(2)]:#,###}} item of tangible property in State K and paid ${{[a(3)]:#,###}} sales tax to the state. It also purchased a ${{[a(4)]:#,###}} item of tangible property in State L and paid ${{[a(5)]:#,###}} sales tax to the state. Firm H transported both items of property into State H for use in its business.

  1. Compute the use tax that Heliot owes to State H for the property purchased in State K.
  2. Compute the use tax that Heliot owes to State H for the property purchased in State L.

 

__ans__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
a.

         
Value of property purchased in State K $ {{[a(2)]:#,###}}    
Use tax rate in State H   {{[a(6)]:#,##0.00}}    
Pre credit use tax $ {{[a(7)]:#,###}}    
Sales tax paid to State K   ({{[a(3)]:#,###}} )  
Use tax owed to State H $ {{[a(8)]:#,###}}    

 

b.

         
Value of property purchased in State L $ {{[a(4)]:#,###}}    
Use tax rate in State H   {{[a(6)]:#,##0.00}}    
Pre credit use tax $ {{[a(9)]:#,###}}    
Sales tax paid to State L   ({{[a(5)]:#,###}} )  
Use tax owed to State H $ 0

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 01-04 Describe the taxes levied by state governments.
Topic: Retail Sales, Use, and Excise Taxes

worksheet.stem:
Heliot Company operates its business in State H, which levies a 6 percent sales and use tax. This year, Heliot purchased a $600,000 item of tangible property in State K and paid $18,000 sales tax to the state. It also purchased a $750,000 item of tangible property in State L and paid $48,750 sales tax to the state. Firm H transported both items of property into State H for use in its business.
 

  1. Compute the use tax that Heliot owes to State H for the property purchased in State K.
  2. Compute the use tax that Heliot owes to State H for the property purchased in State L.

 

__ans__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
a.

         
Value of property purchased in State K $ 600,000    
Use tax rate in State H   0.06    
Pre credit use tax $ 36,000    
Sales tax paid to State K   (18,000 )  
Use tax owed to State H $ 18,000    

 

b.

         
Value of property purchased in State L $ 750,000    
Use tax rate in State H   0.06    
Pre credit use tax $ 45,000    
Sales tax paid to State L   (48,750 )  
Use tax owed to State H $ 0

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 01-04 Describe the taxes levied by state governments.
Topic: Retail Sales, Use, and Excise Taxes

worksheet.stem:
TR Company conducts business exclusively in State V, which levies a {{[a(1)]:#,###}} percent sales and use tax on goods purchased or consumed in-state. This year, TR bought equipment in State B. The cost of the equipment was ${{[a(2)]:#,###}}, and TR paid ${{[a(3)]:#,###}} sales tax to State B. TR also bought machinery in State D. The cost of the machinery was ${{[a(4)]:#,###}}, and TR paid ${{[a(5)]:#,###}} sales tax to State D.

  1. How much use tax does TR Company owe to State V with respect to the equipment bought in State B?
  2. How much use tax does TR Company owe to State V with respect to the machinery bought in State D?

 

__ans__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
a.

         
Value of property purchased in State B $ {{[a(2)]:#,###}}    
Use tax rate in State V   {{[a(6)]:#,##0.00}}    
Pre credit use tax $ {{[a(7)]:#,###}}    
Sales tax paid to State B   ({{[a(3)]:#,###}} )  
Use tax owed to State V $ 0    

 

b.

         
Value of property purchased in State D $ {{[a(4)]:#,###}}    
Use tax rate in State V   {{[a(6)]:#,##0.00}}    
Pre credit use tax $ {{[a(9)]:#,###}}    
Sales tax paid to State D   ({{[a(5)]:#,###}} )  
Use tax owed to State V $ {{[a(10)]:#,###}}

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 01-04 Describe the taxes levied by state governments.
Topic: Retail Sales, Use, and Excise Taxes

worksheet.stem:
TR Company conducts business exclusively in State V, which levies a 5 percent sales and use tax on goods purchased or consumed in-state. This year, TR bought equipment in State B. The cost of the equipment was $90,000, and TR paid $5,400 sales tax to State B. TR also bought machinery in State D. The cost of the machinery was $200,000, and TR paid $7,000 sales tax to State D.

  1. How much use tax does TR Company owe to State V with respect to the equipment bought in State B?
  2. How much use tax does TR Company owe to State V with respect to the machinery bought in State D?

 

__ans__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
a.

         
Value of property purchased in State B $ 90,000    
Use tax rate in State V   0.05    
Pre credit use tax $ 4,500    
Sales tax paid to State B   (5,400 )  
Use tax owed to State V $ 0    

 

b.

         
Value of property purchased in State D $ 200,000    
Use tax rate in State V   0.05    
Pre credit use tax $ 10,000    
Sales tax paid to State D   (7,000 )  
Use tax owed to State V $ 3,000

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 01-04 Describe the taxes levied by state governments.
Topic: Retail Sales, Use, and Excise Taxes

worksheet.stem:
Mrs. Doyle a resident of Rhode Island, traveled to Delaware to purchase an oil painting from a local artist. The cost of the painting was ${{[a(1)]:#,###}}. Rhode Island has a {{[a(2)]:#,###}} percent sales and use tax, while Delaware has no sales and use tax.

  1. How much Rhode Island use tax does Mrs. Doyle owe on the purchase she made in Delaware?
  2. How much Rhode Island use tax would Mrs. Doyle owe if she purchased the painting from a gallery in New York City and paid {{[a(3)]:#,###.00}} percent state and local sales tax on the transaction?
  3. How much Rhode Island use tax would Mrs. Doyle owe if she purchased the painting from a dealer in Milwaukee and paid Wisconsin’s {{[a(4)]:#,###}} percent sales tax on the transaction?

 

__ans__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
1. Mrs. Doyle owes ${{[a(5)]:#,###}} Rhode Island use tax (${{[a(1)]:#,###}} × {{[a(2)]:#,###}}%).
  2. Mrs. Doyle owes no Rhode Island use tax because her ${{[a(6)]:#,###}} New York sales tax (${{[a(1)]:#,###}} × {{[a(3)]:#,###.00}}%) exceeds ${{[a(5)]:#,###}}.
  3. Mrs. Doyle owes ${{[a(7)]:#,###}} Rhode Island use tax (${{[a(5)]:#,###}} − ${{[a(8)]:#,###}} credit for Wisconsin sales tax [${{[a(1)]:#,###}} × {{[a(4)]:#,###}}%]).

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 01-04 Describe the taxes levied by state governments.
Topic: Retail Sales, Use, and Excise Taxes

worksheet.stem:
Mrs. Doyle a resident of Rhode Island, traveled to Delaware to purchase an oil painting from a local artist. The cost of the painting was $9,400. Rhode Island has a 7 percent sales and use tax, while Delaware has no sales and use tax.

  1. How much Rhode Island use tax does Mrs. Doyle owe on the purchase she made in Delaware?
  2. How much Rhode Island use tax would Mrs. Doyle owe if she purchased the painting from a gallery in New York City and paid 8.75 percent state and local sales tax on the transaction?
  3. How much Rhode Island use tax would Mrs. Doyle owe if she purchased the painting from a dealer in Milwaukee and paid Wisconsin’s 5 percent sales tax on the transaction?

 

__ans__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
1. Mrs. Doyle owes $658 Rhode Island use tax ($9,400 × 7%).
  2. Mrs. Doyle owes no Rhode Island use tax because her $823 New York sales tax ($9,400 × 8.75%) exceeds $658.
  3. Mrs. Doyle owes $188 Rhode Island use tax ($658 − $470 credit for Wisconsin sales tax [$9,400 × 5%]).

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 01-04 Describe the taxes levied by state governments.
Topic: Retail Sales, Use, and Excise Taxes

worksheet.stem:
Ms. Pike, who lives in California, traveled to Oregon to purchase gold jewelry for ${{[a(1)]:#,###}}. California has a {{[a(2)]:#,###.00}} percent sales and use tax, while Oregon has no sales and use tax.

  1. Compute the use tax that Ms. Pike owes to California on the jewelry purchased in Oregon.
  2. Compute the use tax that Ms. Pike owes to California if she purchased the jewelry in New Mexico and paid that state’s {{[a(3)]:#,###.000}} percent sales tax on the transaction.
     

__new__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
1. Ms. Pike owes ${{[a(4)]:#,###}} California use tax (${{[a(1)]:#,###}} × {{[a(2)]:#,###.0}}%).
  2. Ms. Pike owes ${{[a(5)]:#,###}} California use tax (${{[a(4)]:#,###}} − ${{[a(6)]:#,###}} credit for New Mexico sales tax [${{[a(1)]:#,###}} × {{[a(3)]:#,###.000}}%]).

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 01-04 Describe the taxes levied by state governments.
Topic: Retail Sales, Use, and Excise Taxes

worksheet.stem:
Ms. Pike, who lives in California, traveled to Oregon to purchase gold jewelry for $20,000. California has a 7.25 percent sales and use tax, while Oregon has no sales and use tax.

  1. Compute the use tax that Ms. Pike owes to California on the jewelry purchased in Oregon.
  2. Compute the use tax that Ms. Pike owes to California if she purchased the jewelry in New Mexico and paid that state’s 5.125 percent sales tax on the transaction.

 

__new__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
1. Ms. Pike owes $1,450 California use tax ($20,000 × 7.25%).
  2. Ms. Pike owes $425 California use tax ($1,450 − $1,025 credit for New Mexico sales tax [$20,000 × 5.125%]).

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 01-04 Describe the taxes levied by state governments.
Topic: Retail Sales, Use, and Excise Taxes

worksheet.stem:
Correll Company, which operates a mail-order clothing business, is physically located in State L. This year, the firm shipped ${{[a(1)]:#,###.0}} million of merchandise to customers in State R. State R imposes a {{[a(2)]:#,###}} percent sales and use tax on the purchase and consumption of retail goods within the state.

  1. Do State R residents who purchased Correll merchandise owe use tax on their purchases?
  2. If State R could legally require Correll to collect a {{[a(2)]:#,###.#}} percent tax on mail-order sales made to residents of the state, how much additional revenue would the state collect?

 

__ans__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
1. State R residents who purchase property out-of-state (i.e., through the mail) but use and consume the property in State R owe the {{[a(2)]:#,###}} percent use tax.
  2. The fact that Correll must collect the State R use tax does not affect the legal liability of State R residents to pay the tax. However, very few people actually pay a self-assessed use tax. Thus, State R might collect as much as ${{[a(3)]:#,###}} additional revenue ({{[a(2)]:#,###}} percent of ${{[a(1)]:#,###.0}} million sales to State R customers) if Correll was required to collect use tax at point of sale and remit the tax to State R.

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 01-04 Describe the taxes levied by state governments.
Topic: Retail Sales, Use, and Excise Taxes

worksheet.stem:
Correll Company, which operates a mail-order clothing business, is physically located in State L. This year, the firm shipped $18 million of merchandise to customers in State R. State R imposes a 6 percent sales and use tax on the purchase and consumption of retail goods within the state.

  1. Do State R residents who purchased Correll merchandise owe use tax on their purchases?
  2. If State R could legally require Correll to collect a 6 percent tax on mail-order sales made to residents of the state, how much additional revenue would the state collect?

 

__ans__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
1. State R residents who purchase property out-of-state (i.e., through the mail) but use and consume the property in State R owe the 6 percent use tax.
  2. The fact that Correll must collect the State R use tax does not affect the legal liability of State R residents to pay the tax. However, very few people actually pay a self-assessed use tax. Thus, State R might collect as much as $1,080,000 additional revenue (6 percent of $18 million sales to State R customers) if Correll was required to collect use tax at point of sale and remit the tax to State R.

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 01-03 Describe the taxes levied by local governments.
Learning Objective: 01-04 Describe the taxes levied by state governments.
Topic: Retail Sales, Use, and Excise Taxes

worksheet.stem:
Mr. and Mrs. Underhill operate a hardware store in a jurisdiction that levies both a sales tax on retail sales of tangible personalty and an annual personal property tax on business tangibles. The personal property tax is based on book value as of December 31. This year, Mr. and Mrs. Underhill  purchased $840,000 of inventory for their store.

 

a. Are Mr. and Mrs. Underhill required to pay sales tax on the purchase of the inventory?

 

__new__

 

b. How can Mr. and Mrs. Underhill minimize their personal property tax by controlling the timing of their inventory purchases?

 

__new1__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
1. Mr. and Mrs. Underhill aren’t required to pay sales tax on the purchase of inventory goods because they aren’t the final consumers of the goods. The hardware store’s retail customers must pay the sales tax when they purchase goods. Mr. and Mrs. Underhill are required to collect this tax at point of sale.
  2. Mr. and Mrs. Underhill should time their purchases to minimize their inventory on hand as of December 31 of each year, thereby minimizing the book value on which the personal property tax is based.

choice.distractor: Minimize inventory on hand as of December 31
Minimize inventory on hand as of March 31
Minimize inventory on hand as of December 1
Minimize inventory on hand as of April 30

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 01-06 Explain the structure of the value-added tax levied by foreign governments.
Topic: Taxes Levied by Foreign Jurisdictions

worksheet.stem:
Querrey Inc. and Ronno Inc. conduct business in a foreign country that imposes a {{[a(1)]:#,###}} percent VAT. Querrey produces entertainment videos at a ${{[a(2)]:#,###.0}} material cost per unit and sells the videos to Ronno for ${{[a(3)]:#,###.0}} per unit. Ronno sells the videos at retail for ${{[a(4)]:#,###.0}} per unit. This year, the combined efforts of Querrey and Ronno resulted in sales of {{[a(5)]:#,###.0}} million videos to the public. Compute the VAT for each corporation. (Enter your answers in dollars not in millions of dollars.)

 

__new__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
Querrey Inc.:
 
         
Sales revenue (${{[a(3)]:#,###.0}} × {{[a(5)]:#,###.0}} million units) $ {{[a(6)]:#,###}}    
Cost of sales (${{[a(2)]:#,###.0}} × {{[a(5)]:#,###.0}} million units)   ({{[a(7)]:#,###}} )  
Value added by Querrey Inc. $ {{[a(8)]:#,###}}    
Tax rate   {{[a(9)]:#,##0.00}}    
VAT $ {{[a(10)]:#,###}}    

 

Ronno Inc.:
 
         
Sales revenue (${{[a(4)]:#,###.0}} × {{[a(5)]:#,###.0}} million units) $ {{[a(11)]:#,###}}    
Material cost of sales (${{[a(3)]:#,###.0}} × {{[a(5)]:#,###.0}} million units)   ({{[a(6)]:#,###}} )  
Value added by Ronno Inc. $ {{[a(12)]:#,###}}    
Tax rate   {{[a(9)]:#,##0.00}}    
VAT $ {{[a(13)]:#,###}}

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 01-06 Explain the structure of the value-added tax levied by foreign governments.
Topic: Taxes Levied by Foreign Jurisdictions

worksheet.stem:
Querrey Inc. and Ronno Inc. conduct business in a foreign country that imposes a 3 percent VAT. Querrey produces entertainment videos at a $6 material cost per unit and sells the videos to Ronno for $9 per unit. Ronno sells the videos at retail for $10 per unit. This year, the combined efforts of Querrey and Ronno resulted in sales of 12.4 million videos to the public. Compute the VAT for each corporation. (Enter your answers in dollars not in millions of dollars.)

 

__new__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
Querrey Inc.:

         
Sales revenue ($9 × 12.4 million units) $ 111,600,000    
Cost of sales ($6 × 12.4 million units)   (74,400,000 )  
Value added by Querrey Inc. $ 37,200,000    
Tax rate   0.03    
VAT $ 1,116,000    

 

Ronno Inc.:

         
Sales revenue ($10 × 12.4 million units) $ 124,000,000    
Material cost of sales ($9 × 12.4 million units)   (111,600,000 )  
Value added by Ronno Inc. $ 12,400,000    
Tax rate   0.03    
VAT $ 372,000

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 01-06 Explain the structure of the value-added tax levied by foreign governments.
Topic: Taxes Levied by Foreign Jurisdictions

worksheet.stem:
Wallis Company produces circuit boards in a foreign country that imposes a {{[a(1)]:#,###}} percent VAT. This year, Wallis manufactured {{[a(2)]:#,###.0}} million boards at a ${{[a(3)]:#,###.00}} material cost per unit. Wallis’s labor and overhead added ${{[a(4)]:#,##0.00}} to the cost per unit. Wallis sold the boards to various customers for ${{[a(5)]:#,###.00}} per unit for a net profit of ${{[a(6)]:#,##0.00}} per unit. How much VAT does Wallis Company owe? (Enter your answer in dollars not in millions of dollars.)

 

__ans__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
Sales revenue (${{[a(5)]:#,###.00}} × {{[a(2)]:#,###.0}} million units) $ {{[a(7)]:#,###}}    
Material cost of sales (${{[a(3)]:#,###.00}} × {{[a(2)]:#,###.0}} million units)   ({{[a(8)]:#,###}} )  
Value added by Wallis Company $ {{[a(9)]:#,###}}    
Tax rate   {{[a(10)]:#,##0.00}}    
VAT $ {{[a(11)]:#,###}}

internal_category.title: Learning Objective: 01-06 Explain the structure of the value-added tax levied by foreign governments.
Topic: Taxes Levied by Foreign Jurisdictions

worksheet.stem:
Wallis Company produces circuit boards in a foreign country that imposes a 15 percent VAT. This year, Wallis manufactured 8.3 million boards at a $5 material cost per unit. Wallis’s labor and overhead added $1 to the cost per unit. Wallis sold the boards to various customers for $7.50 per unit for a net profit of $1.50 per unit. How much VAT does Wallis Company owe? (Enter your answer in dollars not in millions of dollars.)

 

__ans__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
Sales revenue ($7.50 × 8.3 million units) $ 62,250,000    
Material cost of sales ($5 × 8.3 million units)   (41,500,000 )  
Value added by Wallis Company $ 20,750,000    
Tax rate   0.15    
VAT $ 3,112,500
